docs.title: Why a degree project?
docs.text:
The purpose is to provide a unique and challenging opportunity for the student to practice a variety of skills that are required for a successful professional career.

Specifically, the degree project trains the student to:

  • integrate acquired understandings and learnings with past knowledge,
  • independently perform systematic and scientific work
  • apply critical thinking
  • communicate results in an understandable, efficient, mature and correct way

docs.title: Core components
docs.text:
The degree project compromises several key components:

  • Problem solving: each project is developed around a specific research question that generates a problem that should be scientifically addressed by the student.
  • Literature studies: the answer to the problem is put in context of the current scientific knowledge and theories.
  • Scientific writing: the problem, context, and solution is presented and discussed in a scientific report.
  • Oral presentation: the project and its results are presented and defended in public.
  • Peer-reviewing: the student takes an active role in learning from and providing feedback to other students' works.

docs.title: People
docs.text:
During the degree project you will meet people with different roles:

  • Student: You are already an expert in multiple fields, a problem solver, capable of integrating information from different sources and fields, and with knowledge of science theory and methods.
  • Coordinator: Academic staff at KTH. Manages assignment of projects to supervisors and examiners. Schedules presentations and oppositions.
  • Examiner: Academic staff at KTH (often professor). Approves the project specification and examines the final report and presentation. Typically examines multiple theses during the same course.
  • Academic supervisor: Staff at KTH. Supervises multiple theses. Runs group meetings. Provides support on thesis management. Reduces the examiner's work load by assuring that the thesis fulfills the academic requirements.
  • Supervisor at principal's place: Provides expertise to solve the problem.
  • Peer-students

docs.title: Group meetings
docs.text:
A group consists of one academic supervisor and typically four to six students. They meet regularly throughout the course. The purpose of the group meetings is to:

  • provide information and help the student throughout the project
  • make efficient use of resources, advice and experiences (good and bad ones) with each other. Many of the problems that the students encounter are general and can be solved together.
  • increase the quality of each other's projects
  • evenly distribute the project work load over time (e.g. using assignments)
  • break the isolation that may come with the project
  • indirectly and directly prepare for oral presentation (we talk, describe, defend ideas and thoughts on our projects)
  • gain confidence as writers (by seeing how other experience and handle a similar process)
  • inspire each other

docs.title: Peer reviewing
docs.text:
This section describes general ideas on peer-reviewing in the context of the degree project.

REMEMBER

"Att samarbeta på det här sättet kräver en del av dem som ska vara med. Om det blir så att bara några få tar det på allvar, medan andra betraktar denna arbetsform som en möjlighet att på ett lättvindligt sätt skaffa sig en examen, blir det problematiskt. Det är oerhört viktigt att man skapar grupper där man känner att man får något tillbaka, samtidigt som man känner att man själv kan komma med vettiga bidrag."

Torlaug Løkensgard Hoel, "Skriva på universitet och högskolor", Studentlitteratur, 2010

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
The peer-review process is aimed to improve the students' skills on:

  • critical reading
  • scientific writing
  • giving and receiving criticism

Above are all invaluable skills, no matter what the student end up doing after graduation.

In addition, the peer-reviewing process is aimed to indirectly enhance the students' comprehension of the evaluation criteria.

A desired outcome of the peer-reviewing process is that the quality of the reviewed texts increase significantly.

docs.title: Types of feedback
docs.text:
READER-BASED: How do you as a reader feel and react on the text?

KNOWLEDGE-BASED: For example, are the methods correctly described and used?

CRITERIA-BASED: How well does the assignment agree with the evaluation criteria?

WRITING-BASED: There are many aspects of scientific writing that can and should be reviewed, including:

  • content: has the text a clear focus? Is the current text relevant for that focus?
  • structure and composition: is the text appropriately divided into clear and consequent sections? Do section titles help to create structure, connections, and understanding?
  • integration of knowledge and theories: are there any clarifying examples of theories and concepts? Are they helpful for understanding?
  • selection and implementation of methods,
  • use of references,
  • reasoning,
  • novelty and creativity,
  • terminology and language: correct and consequent use? definition of abbreviatons?

docs.title: Constructive feedback
docs.text:
Feedback should be constructive. Aim to:

  • highlight the text's strong/good parts
  • express what is not clear or what concepts and descriptions are difficult to understand,
  • suggest a direction for any unfinished parts
  • inspire the author to improve the text

docs.title: The feedback process
docs.text:
Below is a general suggestion on how to approach peer-reviewing tasks.

Before reading:

  • Identify the aspects of the assignment that should be addressed in the text.
  • Try to completely neglect who is the author of the text you will comment on.

First reading:

  • What is your spontaneous feeling about it?
  • Can you identify the text's strength and weakness?

Repeated reading:

  • Read slowly and carefully. Meanwhile, comment on anything that gets your attention (good and bad).
  • When finished, categorize your draft comments (e.g. content, structure, language, references, ... see above)
  • Prioritize the comments within each of your categories. Decide which comments are most important to address in order to improve the text?
  • Suggest improvements/changes for your most important comment(s).
  • Check and complete any task-specific peer-reviewing instructions.

Afterwards

Ask yourself:

  • would your comments/suggestions potentially influence the first-impression reading?
  • are your comments clear and well-argued?
  • are your comments free from any personal reference?
  • is there anything in the reviewed text that you could apply to your own assignment text?
  • do you fulfill the recommendations listed below (tips)

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Create a win-win situation

Take the peer-reviewing feedback seriously. If you return highly thought-through comments to your peer-author, you

  1. have acquired valuable experience in scientific writing,
  2. will inspire her/him to immerse in the next peer-reviewing task.

It is a win-win situation.

REMEMBER

We are all sensible when it comes to receive feedback on our work.

In this course, the reviewed texts often contain unfinished thoughts and content. Don't feel uncomfortable about that.

REMEMBER

As a peer-reviewer you are a reader, not an evaluator.

Note

As an author, do not hesitate to request specific feedback from your peer-reviewers on sections that you feel insecure about or have trouble to develop.

KNOWLEDGE-BASED feedback

Although not the main focus for the peer-reviewing tasks, we cannot overlook the fact that many theses touch on similar topics. Feel free to comment on choice of methods, their implementation and application if appropriate.

Warning

Avoid feedback that is vague, generic, negative, or intimidating

Warning

Avoid to focus on small grammatical issues (except for the very final report).

docs.title: Presentation
docs.text:
While initially perhaps frightening, oral presentation of papers can be an exciting, exhilarating, efficient, and rewarding scientific activity.

The goal is to communicate science to your colleagues, whom you respect and who respect you, as they certainly will when you are finished with your presentation.

docs.title: Keys to a successful presentation
docs.text: A successful presentation requires careful planning and clear structure. A common error is to start to prepare the slides for the presentation in advance of having planned and structured the presentation.

docs.title: Planning
docs.text:
Start the planning early on. Collect ideas for the presentation already when writing the report. Think about what needs to be argued and explained. Specifically, it is recommended to think through the following aspects of the presentation:

Define your objective - What do you want to achieve? What do you want your audience to take away with them?* Formulate your "Thesis statement", a sentence that summarizes your argument.

Know your audience - How much will your audience already know about your topic? How can you link new material to things they might already understand?

Venue - What equipment is available? (Sound, video, light, etc)

Remit - How long do you have to speak? Q&A? Are you being graded? If so, what are the criteria?

KTH presentation conditions

Time 20-25 min; Questions from opponent; Open discussion (audience); Questions from examiner.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
Structure is EVERYTHING.

In contrast to the report, the structure of the presentation has more degrees of freedom. It does not have to follow a particular order but can (and should) be adapted to the speaker, content, and audience. Nevertheless, a common core structure is as follows:

  • Introduction: create interest and goodwill. ställ en fråga, presentera dig, gör ett påstående...
  • Background: Utgångspunkter, "trailer" (layout), definitioner. Bli inte för långrandig
  • Main body: argue, explain, inform, (adapt to content and situation)
  • Conclusion: Summarize, reconnect to intro/background, look forward, give recommendations

That said, above core structure could basically be reversed, which typically leaves more room for what is really important in the presentation.

No matter the structure, it is important that the audience is guided through the content and that the speaker motivates WHY something is relevant, important, or relevant.

Tell them what you are going to tell them: Arouse the audience's attention. Connect to audience's knowledge and previous experience. Use logic, offer new perspectives. Present novelty. What is your expertise? Try to be likable.

Tell it to them: Give evidence. What facts, figures, examples, and references can you use to support every point you make?. It is Important to make a POINT and evaluate the evidences.

Tell them what you told them: Reinforce the message. Urge understanding.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Select parts of the report to present. Avoid to pack too much into the talk. Perhaps we do this out of insecurity, feeling that we have found out so little to impress an audience that we need to make up for it in sheer volume.

  • If you get a question from the opponent or the audience: it is often very good to repeat the question so that everyone is aware of what have been asked.

  • Prepare your equipment. Check that it works on site.

Assignment A2 concerns the pre-study.

The process is divided into four stages (A2.0 - A2.4).

docs.title: Prerequisite
docs.text:
Approved project specification

A2.0 - Explore old theses

Step 1) Search and download three different student theses from the KTH DiVA portal.

Search category: Independent thesis Advanced level (degree of Master (Two Years)) Search topic: something relevant for your own project

Step 2) For each thesis, identify the section(s) derived from the literature study. Look at structure and what topics are discussed.

Step 3) Add below data to the shared spreadsheet (link provided in separate email)

  • Title
  • How many are the total pages?
  • How many pages are dedicated to content related to the pre-study?
  • How many references are listed in the bibliography (# of references)?

A2.1 - Pre-study step 1

Perform the literature search to collect candidate papers relevant for the pre-study. Organize your literature and take notes on the papers while reading.

When a significant amount of literature has been found, then use the notes to roughly plan your pre-study according to the instructions.

  • Which topics (sections) will be discussed around in the pre-study, and with what granularity?
  • Which are the main sources that will be used for each section?
  • What are the main arguments that justifies the research methodology that will be used to answer the research question?

Report above to the academic supervisor in a simple and informal format (e.g. sections with bullet points). Time dedication: about two weeks.

A2.2 - Pre-study step 2

Write the pre-study](./writing.md). Time dedication: about one week.

A2.3 - Peer-reviewing

Each student will perform one peer-review activity associated to the pre-study. The text to review will be facilitated by the academic supervisor.

docs.title: Evaluation
docs.text:
The pre-study is presented in a written report. The report is structured so that it can be recycled as a separate chapter in the final written report.

Criteria for the background section of the final report:

The scientific field of work is well introduced. The background contains a written review of previous research and development, and the student's own work is designed in accordance with the conclusions of this review. Work related to the state of the art of knowledge are described.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text:
• Learn from the experts! Visit the events offered by the KTH library.
    • Find, Evaluate & Cite!
    • Reference Management Software-Basic Introduction
  • Search
    • If a "seed" paper exists, start to search using citation chaining. Go both backward and forward in the citation chain.
    • Search systematically using multiple and different keywords. It is important to try to capture as many ways as possible to express an idea.
    • Use different databases.
    • Keep track of the used search terms (so the search can be reproduced if needed).
    • Aim to browse through large amounts of papers. It is perfectly normal to explore ten times as many papers as will be included in the final literature report.
    • Keep a list of literature that could not be retrieved (e.g. due to paywall). Consult with the library / the supervisor.
    • Schedule a least 20 hours to do the literature search and initial skimming of papers for relevance.
  • Read
    • While reading, take notes. Write down interesting pieces of information, insights about how to organize your pre-study, thoughts on what to write, etc.
    • Use a reference manager from the very beginning.
    • Use quotation marks if you are provisionally copying verbatim from the literature into your notes.
  • Write
    • Start with a draft to build a coherent structure towards a logical argument.
    • Initially focus on the latter sections (state-of-the-art, summary)
    • Write only when the idea is clear.

docs.title: Reviewing information
docs.text: Before getting started with the pre-study it can easily seem like a tough mission to read up on all the relevant literature. However, reading a scientific article is not the same as reading a normal textbook. While the latter is typically read from cover to cover, a research article is often divided into separate sections that can be read separately (similar to how a normal newspaper is divided into different sections). This division, in combination with clever search strategies, makes it easy to efficiently browse large amounts of research literature in little time and to build a core of candidate papers for the pre-study.

docs.title: Browsing literature
docs.text:
When browsing the literature, articles are skimmed through rather than read critically. When skimming through a paper the reading is not linear. For example, the order of reading could be:

  1. title: What is the paper about?
  2. abstract: provides a concise overview of the paper,
  3. introduction: look for motivations, relation to other work, and a more detailed overview,
  4. conclusions: What are the main result?
  5. overall structure of the paper:
    • What do the remaining sections address?
    • What is new or different about this work?

If relevant, add the paper to your reference manager software to not loose track of it. If at any point the research article is irrelevant for the degree project, then discard it and move on to the next article.

docs.title: Reading research papers
docs.text:
When relevant papers have been identified they should be read carefully.

  • Focus on the body of the paper (results, discussion) and pay attention to the details.
  • Take notes as you read. For each key paper, assess:
    • research question
    • key findings / arguments
    • supporting evidence / sample characteristics / methods
    • strengths / limitations
    • significance / implications
    • relevance
  • Explore the references (for citation chaining search strategy).

docs.title: Literature search
docs.text:
The pre-study starts with a thorough literature search for information that:

  1. make observations on the research problem,
  2. document the need to answer the research question,
  3. contain data related to the research question that can be analyzed and/or discussed,
  4. describe models, methods, concepts that can be used to answer the research question.

Common sources of information are full-text research articles, review articles, conference proceedings, manuals, textbooks, business reports, code libraries, etc.

It is important that the sources are valid and can be trusted. For that purpose it is recommended to rely on academic literature that has undergone thorough scientific revision.

docs.title: Academic literature
docs.text:
Most scientific literature is subject to a rigorous peer-review process. It means that academic articles are carefully reviewed by impartial experts in the field. The peer reviewers are volunteers, and they help to ensure that the article is meaningful and that the research is accurate and has been professionally executed.

As a reader of a scientific text it is good practice to check if the text has been subject to peer reviewing.

docs.title: Access
docs.text:
Although research is often funded by public sources, academic literature is a commercial business and access to scientific information often requires subscription to the journals that publishes the research. The university library provides access to most (but not all) relevant scientific journals.

To increase the access to knowledge, the scientific community has adopted principles of open-access. Researchers who want to spread their work and make it publically accessible basically have three options:

  1. To pay an extra (but not insignificant) fee to the editorial in order to grant the research article open-access status (i.e. readers can bypass the subscription paywall).
  2. To publish the research in truly open-access journal.
  3. To deposit the research in open-access repositories.

The amount of high-quality peer-reviewed open-access journals is increasing rapidly. While a subscription paywall typically means that a journal is serious about peer-reviewing, open access journals are many times equally rigorous about it. Nevertheless, the explosion of electronic journals has led to mass publication of a large number of scientific articles with little or no peer review.

docs.title: Databases
docs.text:
There exist dedicated search engines and databases for scholary information. All databases accessible via the KTH library are available here. They include,

  • Web of Science: a service provided by The Thomson Reuters Corporation that covers a broad range of scientific discipline (including computer science). Access provided via the KTH library.
  • Google Scholar: easy to use and has a wide coverage. However, no clear criteria what makes its results "scholary".
  • arXiv: open-access archive of scholarly articles that not yet have been reviewed by experts (i.e. a repository of draft research articles).
  • The directory of open access journal (DOAJ) is a community-curated online directory that indexes and provides access to high quality, open access, peer-reviewed journals.

It is highly recommended to explore and use a variety of databases since they have different conditions and content. Often you get different citations in Google Scholar than in Web of Science.

Also, explore the DIVA database to read theses from previous years.

docs.title: Impact factors
docs.text:
Correct or not, scientific journals can be ranked by their impact factor (IF). A higher value typically indicates that the journal publishes important and relevant findings, that are often referred to (cited) by researchers in other works. The journal's impact factor can be a first indicator of how relevant a research article is.

Briefly, the IF is calculated for a specific period of time (e.g. two years). During that period,

IF = (number of citations for recent articles) / (number of recent articles).

Note that not all journals have IFs (e.g., it takes two years for a new journal to obtain its IF score), and the IF does not measure the true scientific value of an individual article.

The Journal Citation Reports (JCR) database lists IFs for thousands of journals. In addtion, scientific journals usually publish their current IF score on their websites.

docs.title: Search strategies
docs.text: There are two major search strategies that both should be explored during the degree project: systematic search and citation chaining.

docs.title: Systematic literature search
docs.text:
1. Planning: Define key search terms and research areas based on the research question. Consider possible synonyms, related terms, abbreviations, etc.
  2. Select databases: It is important to use different databases.
  3. Search: Explore different combinations of keywords and search terms
  4. Reflection: Scan through search results. Pay attention to terms and vocabulary. Oftentimes one can find new but relevant search terms from the search results. If so, repeat from step three.
  5. Documentation: Document the searches so that they can be reproduced later if necessary.

docs.title: Citation chaining
docs.text:
1. Start with a single paper ("seed" paper) that is close to the work and/or that describes the topic particularly well.
  2. Go backward in the citation chain by pulling all the relevant papers cited within the "seed" paper.
  3. To go forward in the citation chain, explore what other papers have cited the "seed" paper.

Advantage: If the "seed" paper is good, this typically leads from one good reference to another. It allows to follow how the arguments are built from one study to another.

Drawback: One may miss out on parallel lines of research.

docs.title: Pre-study
docs.text:
The pre-study (also known as reading stage, literature study, background study) is the foundation of any scientific work. Its purpose is to facilitate in-depth knowledge about the research topic in order to contextualize the research question and support the approach to address it.

Specifically, the pre-study should:

  • convince the reader that the research area is interesting, significant, and important,
  • provide the historical context for the research area and showcase related work (state-of-the-art),
  • explain and justify the choice of theoretical framework,
  • demonstrate that the proposed research methods are sound and reasonable,
  • introduce relevant terminology and provide definitions to clarify how terms are to be used.

In simple terms, the process is described by:

  1. A thorough literature search.
  2. A detailed review of selected research papers
  3. Writing up necessary theory and state-of-the-art to justify the research.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
There is no template or one-must-follow structure for the pre-study. Nevertheless, for the purpose of the final report it is recommended to start with a general introduction of the context, followed by an exposition of the necessary theory (background), then a recapitulation of the related work (i.e. state-of-the-art for the research area) and finally a summary that justifies the proposed methodology to answer the research question.

Introduction to research area -> Theory -> Related work -> Summary -> (References)

The two first parts (introduction and theory) are typically more general, while the two last parts are very specific to each degree project.

docs.title: State-of-the-art
docs.text:
In general, a good review of the state-of-the-art does not only summarize the literature, but discusses it critically, identifies methodological problems, and points out research gaps. A common structure for the state-of-the-art is:

  1. Short summary of the historically most important advances in the field up to today (How has thinking in this area evolved over time?).
  2. Which are the best solutions to solve the problem described?
  3. Why are the proposed solutions not enough to solve the current problem? Identify the knowledge gap that the project will address.
  4. Finally, put the planned research into perspective of what has been discussed up to this point. What are the grounds for believing that the research hypotheses are likely to be true and worth investigating?

  • it is plausible to answer the research question ...

    2. using scientific arguments,

Does the project specification

  • provide enough information for you to answer the question in assignment A1.0?

Send the feedback to the corresponding student + the academic supervisor.

Address the feedback received on the project specification from your peer and send it to supervisor.

docs.title: Project specification
docs.text:
The project specification is a written document that presents and plans the research to be performed. Importantly, it

  • defines the research question,
  • defines the research methodology to answer above question,
  • contextualizes the research question and methodology, and motivates its relevance based on current knowledge (state-of-the-art)
  • defines and schedules key tasks (milestones)
  • defines deliverables that can be used to measure project progress

The specification sets the stage for the research to be performed. It is later used to measure project progress against the proposed schedule, milestones, and deliverables. Finally, it constitutes the core material for the 'Introduction' chapter of the final report.

How is the project specification different from the project proposal?

The project specification is a significant extension and deepening of the project proposal. It should carefully validate the research question and methodology against scientific literature, as well as list potential complications and important constraints.

A well-prepared specification will save you much time, effort and resources.

IMPORTANT

It is the responsibility of the student to inform the supervisor on the work progress. A specific reasons to contact the supervisor is if the specification must be changed.

Position the degree project in an academic context.

  • What is its research territory? Explain by introducing relevant previous research in the field (i.e. state-of-the-art).

  • What concerns/questions/problems exist in the current context? This defines your "niche" in the academic and/or R&D context.

  • What is the objective (aim)? It explains why one wants to answer the research question. What will the answer be used for?

Objectives

The degree project objective is typically a smaller part of the principal's objective.

docs.title: Research question and methods
docs.text:
• The QUESTION that will be examined. Formulated as an explicit and evaluable question.
  • Specified problem definition (e.g. what does the assignment entail, what are the challenges involved?)
  • Examination method: Preliminary description of, for example, algorithms that will be tested, data that will be used
  • Expected scientific results: How is the work scientifically relevant and what is the hypothesis being tested? How is the hypothesis being tested?

The research question is at the core of your project. The quality of it will decide the quality of your project. Therefore, work HARD to define the exact question that you want to address.

Some advice:

  • It is IMPORTANT that the research question is well-defined and well formulated.

  • The research question should be of general interest (and not only aimed for the principal).

  • Narrow down the research question to a very limited area. Introduce constraints, but always explain their reasons.

  • It is not the topic itself that determines the quality of the research question. Rather, the important is that the question really allows you to elaborate a scientifically well-argued answer to the question.

  • Include all necessary elements in the research question. For example, it is usually not feasible to state the question without mentioning somehow what methods are to be used.

  • Related to above point, already when formulating the question one should consider how to argue for the answer.

  • The research question should also somehow reflect the empirical foundation of the project.

  • Continuously (re)evaluate your research question. It is perfectly normal to have to rewrite it many times until one settles on the final formulation.

  • It is not easy to ask the right question. While you need appropriate sources to state your question, it should be the question rather than the sources that build the thesis.

  • The answer to the research question should reduce the possibility space to reach the objective.

  • One can formulate > 1 question. If so, make sure that there is one clear main question, and that all questions relate to each other.

REMEMBER 1

It is usually more valuable to say something well-founded on a small problem than to speculate widely on a large and socially important problem.

REMEMBER 2

The natural way for the examiner to evaluate the written thesis is to compare its outcome with the research question. Keep in mind that while ambitious research questions may be attractive, you are only evaluated on what you produce.

REMEMBER 3

At rare occasion, the research question will be completely reformulated when the project finishes (depends on the analysis of the collected material). We shall try to avoid this though.

Warning

Don't:

  • seek supporting evidence for a preconceived idea
  • ask an unanswerable question
  • ask a useless question

Engineering students often have a quite clear idea of the research methods they will use when they start their project. Often the research question is formulated based on the available methods.

It is important that all research methods are mentioned and motivated with respect to literature (state-of-the-art) and the project context.

IMPORTANT

If the methods require training datasets from external part, it is highly recommended that the student acquires them as early as possible.

If an hypothesis exists, it should preferentially be mentioned in close connection to the research question. Give brief background on how the hypothesis has been generated, and what assumptions have been made that can support it.

docs.title: General writing tips
docs.text:
Read, read, read

Spend significant time to find and read high-quality literature relevant for your research topic. It will help you to choose your methods and to narrow down your research question.

Writing is a continuous process

A good project description is not written in one day. It has to mature. Therefore, create a draft on the very first day, and then continuously edit it (add/remove/change/reconsider) until you hand it in.

Get some distance to your text

Before you hand it in, give your self some distance to your specification. Let it rest for a day, before you return to read it with fresh and critical eyes.

Learn from previous thesis works

Use the library to find published engineering master's theses. Explore many theses, both in your own and in other fields.

  • What common structure do they all share?
  • Are the research questions stated implicitly or explicitly?
  • How have the students narrowed down their research question?
  • Focus on the introductory chapters. How do they relate to Assignment 1?

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
The project specification presents a plan for the research to be performed. A well prepared project specification is fundamental for a successful project, as it

  • defines the research question,
  • exposes the research methodology that will be used to answer above question,
  • defines important constraints and challenges,
  • identifies and schedules key tasks (milestones and deliverables) that can be used to measure project progress.

Importantly, the project specification contextualizes and justifies both the research question and methodology based on the current scientific knowledge (state-of-the-art).

docs.title: Research question
docs.text: Last updated: 2019-01-20

docs.title: Research question and methods
docs.text:
From the course information

  • The QUESTION that will be examined. Formulated as an explicit and evaluable question.
  • Specified problem definition (e.g. what does the assignment entail, what are the challenges involved?)
  • Examination method: Preliminary description of, for example, algorithms that will be tested, data that will be used
  • Expected scientific results: How is the work scientifically relevant and what is the hypothesis being tested? How is the hypothesis being tested?

The research question is at the core of the degree project. It guides and centers the research by narrowing down the general research area to a limited scope, and explicitly stating what the thesis will investigate and by which means.

A well-composed research question helps to construct a logical argument for a clear answer and conclusion (thesis statement) which in turn help to reduce the possibility space to reach the thesis objective.

In the end, the success of the project depends on how well the research question is answered.

docs.title: Research methods
docs.text:
The empirical foundation of the project naturally shapes the research question, and in applied research (engineering and technology) it is not uncommon that the research methods themselves drive the research question formulation. Nevertheless, it is much preferable that the question rather than the methods build the thesis.

Importantly, the project specification should account for a brief but motivated description of the research methodology and the characteristics of the data expected to be collected (e.g. type, dataset size, availability, accuracy, completeness, etc). Specifically, it is necessary to explain how the research question is supposed to be evaluated (by what means and given what circumstances).

docs.title: Research question
docs.text:
The research question should be:

  • focused (narrow down the research topic so the question can be addressed within the allocated time),
  • clear and concise (formulate a question that is short, sharp and to the point),
  • complex (don't seek supporting evidence for preconceived ideas; don't ask unanswerable questions; don't formulate questions that can be answered with a simple YES or NO),
  • arguable (the answer to the question should be interpretable and open for discussion),
  • interesting (it should be of general interest and not only for researcher and the principal),
  • (measurable).

docs.title: Process
docs.text:
It is not easy to ask the right question, and it is many times not known at the beginning of the project. In order to develop and formulate a good research question:

  1. Gather information on the broader topic to explore possibilities and to help narrow down your topic to a limited scope.
  2. Generate multiple candidate questions.
  3. Estimate the equilibrium between complexity, feasibility, news value of each candidate question. Can these parameters be controlled, e.g. by introducing constraints?
  4. Identify research variables involved in the study.
  5. Consider characteristics of data (availability, type, size, accuracy, completeness, ...)
  6. Select the best candidate question.

  7. Formulate the research question. As its name suggests, research questions are always written as questions. For example, start the research question with "What ...", "Does ...", "How ...", "To what extent ..." etc. A quantitative research question could follow this template:

    Does x (name the theory) explain the relationship between y (independent variable) and z (dependent variable), controlling for the effects of w (control variable)?

  8. Ensure the research question is focused, clear, concise, complex, measurable, and arguable.

  9. Consider the path your answer might take and how to argue for the answer.
  10. Continuously (re)evaluate and refine your research question. It is perfectly normal to rewrite the research question many times until one settles on the final formulation. Nevertheless, being able to formulate a good research question at an early stage of the project puts the researcher on a good way to write a strong thesis.

One can at occasion need to formulate more than one question. In such case, make sure that there is one main question, and that all questions relate to each other. List the questions in order of relevance.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Below are listed a few examples of M.Sc. research questions with comments.

Example

"To what extent can autoencoders be used for feature extraction in the context of clothing images?"

+ Specifies method (autoencoders), application (feature extraction), context (clothing images) - Need to specify the autoencoders (e.g. type, number, etc). - It is not clear how the success of feature extraction is measured.

Example

"Will clustering algorithm X yield better in-cluster compactness when performed on the customer database than when performed on random data?"

+ Clearly specifies which measure is to be used to evaluate the investigation (in-cluster compactness). - Too tight connection to the principal's customer database. Try to generalize better.

Example

"How well does a deep learning approach to predict diagnosis code for EHRs perform compared to Random Forest?""

+ Explains which measure to use to evaluate the answer. - Improve focus by specifying the type of deep learning approach

Example

"To what extent can machine learning be used to automatically appraise commercial real estate?"

- Improve focus: What machine learning are we talking about? How is success measured? What aspect of commercial real estate is considered?

docs.title: Advice
docs.text:
• It is usually more valuable to say something well-founded on a small problem than to speculate widely on a large but important problem.

  • The examiner evaluates the thesis by comparing the outcome to the research question. Keep in mind that while ambitious research questions may be attractive, the student is only evaluated on what (s)he produces.

  • It is not the topic itself that determines the quality of the research question. Rather, the important is that the question really allows you to elaborate a scientifically well-argued answer to the question.

docs.title: Conditions and schedule
docs.text:
From the course information

  • List of the resources expected to be needed to solve the problem (unless the degree project involves investigating what equipment should be used). This can be technical equipment, but also experiment and interview subjects.
  • Defined limitations on what is to be done (so that it is clear what is not included in the degree project)
  • Collaboration with the principal (external supervisor). Describe the way in which the principal will be involved in the project and what the external supervisor has undertaken to do (e.g. in terms of discussion, implementation, report reading).
  • Schedule showing not only the order in which elements will be performed, but also the scope of elements and when they will be performed (calendar week number or date). The schedule should contain clear intermediate goals.

Limitations:

  • Consider potential confidentiality issues from your principal. Remember that the KTH examination is based solely on the report that is made public.

Confidentiality

If handling confidential data etc at the principal, note that:

  • All MSc thesis projects are public and published in Diva.
  • it is the public version of the thesis report that is assessed by the examiner. NO exceptions that the examiner sees e.g. an unmasked version. The public report must contain everything required to assess it (if the student wants to make another company-internal report with confidential details, this is fine, but this confidential report can not be the grounds for assessment)

Compose a time plan:

  • List all possible tasks that need to be performed throughout the full degree project (20 weeks). Break up large tasks into smaller tasks if appropriate.

  • Schedule important milestones (control points; do not forget to include revision time needed by the supervisor and/or the examiner), e.g.

    • Deliver project specification
    • Deliver pre-study
    • Deliver half-time report
    • Deliver final report
    • Make oral presentation
    • Make opposition
    • Assist at two seminars (oral presenations by other students)
    • Research specific tasks (e.g. "training data is acquired")

  • Identify and schedule major tasks, e.g

    • Prepare project specification
    • Perform literature search
    • Write pre-study
    • Execute research (specify subtasks!)
    • Report writing
    • Prepare and assay presentation

  • Additional complimentary tasks.

  • Estimate how much devotion each task requires (in weeks), or when in time the milestones should be achieved. For the oral presentation and oppostion, see figure for an indication of when students typically present their work throughout the year.

  • The time dedicated to solve the problem (i.e. implementation phase) should typically not exceed 50% of the total time dedicated to the degree project.

  • Lay out all above tasks in a time chart (Gannt charts are popular) and in a logical order. Tasks can run in parallel with each other (for example the report writing should run in parallel to other tasks).

  • Prepare for unforeseen situations and add compensation time towards the end.

  • Ambition is admired in a research project. The implementation plan, however, should be realistic. It is the responsibility of the student to inform the supervisor if the execution of the time plan is delayed more than two weeks.

Ideal time schedule

  • present around midsummer (week before or after) which means that
  • the coordinator needs to schedule the presentation by mid-June,
  • the examiner needs to get the presentation report in early June (around first week of June, check with your examiners)
  • the supervisor need to get the presentation report some time during the second half of May in order to be able to iterate it with the student.

Definition: “presentation report” = a report that is more or less finished, but does not need to be the final version. It should be in such a state that the examiner can assess it favourably and that an opponent can make a good review on it.

docs.text:
Required content:

  • Research objectives and question(s)
  • Background / Related work
  • Related theory
  • Methods

Above content should be distributed according to the standard core structure and further refined by a detailed structure.

The table of content should be complete with all sections that the report will contain (i.e. main headings and subheadings). Obviously, future changes are allowed if necessary.

The methods and result sections should contain relevant subheadings with the important concepts in bullet points.

docs.title: A3.1 - Attend two seminars
docs.text:
It is compulsory to attend two master's thesis presentations.

Available seminars

Tip

If possible, try to attend at least one seminar with your own examiner.

Before presentation

  • familiarize yourself with the thesis to be presented (it is posted).
  • read through the opponent record and think about answers to the questions

After presentation

For both presentations, report to academic supervisor (by email, pdf file):

  • General info: title, date, examiner.
  • Briefly describe the structure of the presentation. For example,
    • which clear sections / components could be distinguished?
    • did the sections translate to the sections in the written report?

  • Briefly describe the opposition.
    • How many questions?

docs.title: Report: Background
docs.text:
The background section should cover three areas:

  • relevant theory
  • related work (state-of-the-art)
  • proposed methodology to answer the research question

Much of the content of the pre-study maps directly to the background chapter.

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
The background section

  • contains a description of the relevant theory necessary to understand the concepts in the report,
  • exposes the different and possible ways to answer the research question,
  • relates past works to each other and to the current project,
  • highlights what the important findings/methods are relative their own work,
  • clearly justifies the chosen methodology,
  • contains in-text citations (references) where statements need to be supported by other sources of information,
  • tells a coherent story with a logical flow.

docs.title: Report: Conclusions
docs.text:
A short section (typically one paragraph) that summarizes the conclusions of the study. It should offer a clear ending (preferably a citable statement).

Assure that the conclusions

  • are well supported by the results,

  • are reasonable and concrete,

  • associate with objectives/research question.

docs.title: Report: Discussion
docs.text:
The Discussion section is where the results are interpreted, and the foundation for the conclusions are laid out. Its purpose is very clear, namely to

  • summarize the main findings
  • put the findings into context by comparing with previous work,
  • discuss future implications and any shortcomings of the research design.

docs.title: Content
docs.text:
The content of the Discussion section should assure that below questions can be properly answered by reader:

  • What was found?
  • What was known before, and what is new?
  • How does the new results fit in a broader picture? (Are the findings important?)
  • Are the findings true? (Any limitation of the study?)
  • What can be done with the findings?

The content of the Discussion therefore naturally has tight connection to the content of both the Introduction and the Results section.

Note

The discussion is subjective. A reader may have a different interpretation of the results than the author.

docs.title: Composition
docs.text:
There are no absolute rules how to write the Discussion. Nevertheless, its content should be systematically presented.

While the Introduction starts broadly and then narrows down to the particular research question, the Discussion typically starts with the narrowest part (main findings) and then gradually widens out to comparisons with other studies and the interpretation of the results in the wider context of the research topic.

       Go from the general, broad context of your work,
           to tell the reader what is already known,
                to what is not yet known or,
                   what the problems are,
                     to what you have
                         decided
                          to do

                    Methods and results
    (i.e. the original part of the study = contribution)

                           After
                        summarizing
                    the results, identify
                   limitations and biases,
                 compare and contrast them
              with previous findings and discuss
          theoretical and practical implications of your
         own, make cautious speculations and suggest future
      research, show what is new and how your results fit into
  the broad field you described at the  beginning of the introduction

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Discuss one question at the time. Avoid jumping back and forth. Make the reader aware of where they are being led.

  • For each point that is discussed, order simple to complex (building to conclusion).

  • Remind the reader of the knowledge gap identified in the Introduction to re-spark curiosity about the question you have set out to answer.

  • Be frank about acknowledging limitations.

  • Avoid to repeat results.

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
• The most important results have been emphasized and critically evaluated.

  • The discussion section does not present new results.

  • The findings are interpreted against the settings of the study (conditions and limitations)

  • The findings are interpreted and discussed in a broader context, and connects back to the existing literature.

  • Statements and conclusions are well supported by the results.

  • Conclusions are reasonable, concrete, and associates with objectives/research question.

  • It is stated how the study fills the knowledge gap pointed out in the Introduction, and how the results have moved the field forward.

  • Each research question leads to new questions. The most relevant ones are mentioned.

docs.title: Report: Introduction
docs.text:
As the name suggests, this section should provide a general introduction to the topic and the motivation for the research question.

Important content of the introduction maps to sections in the project specification. For example,

  • objective
  • research question
  • conditions and limitations

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
The introduction

  • is written in such a way that non-experts can appreciate the motivation for the study
  • explicitly contains the research questions.
  • explains the aim behind the research,
  • explains the conditions that surrounds the study and that has shaped the research question

docs.title: Report: Methodology
docs.text:
A scientific report should never present personal opinions or argue for preconceived biases. Therefore the methodology section (sometimes "Methods" or "Materials and Methods") is a critical part of the report, as it provides the information by which the validity of the study is ultimately judged.

This section focuses only on the technical aspects of the procedure necessary to answer the research question. While the procedure and the different methods contained within are often justified elsewhere in the report (e.g. in the Background section), the methodology section should provide enough information so that:

  • the audience can judge whether the results and conclusions are valid
  • the experiment(s) could be repeated by the readers if they wish. This could be in order to evaluate whether the results are reproducible, or prepare identical material for further investigation.

This section is quite analogous to a recipe in a cookery book. It lists ingredients and procedures but does not specify the use of particular equipment.

docs.title: Content
docs.text:
The methods section is typically the most straightforward part to write as it simply describes what was done, how it was done, in what order, and how it was evaluated. It should thus include a description of

  • material (e.g. input data, hardware resources)
  • procedures (e.g. algorithms, data processing, etc)
  • evaluation approach (e.g. analysis/statistical tools)

The methods applied in the project are rarely new (if they were, they themselves should be evaluated and justified in a scientific report). Thus, one can often find literature where a particular method has been applied and described in similar settings. Such references greatly facilitates the writing process of the methods section.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Begin writing the methodology while performing/implementing experiments. (It is easy to forget details).

  • If the procedure is complex or diverse, divide methods into subsections. Often, the same subsections can often be applied in the "Results" section.

  • While writing, take notes on problems, issues, doubts, potential methodological improvements, that come to your mind. These notes will make a good framework for issues to discuss around in the "Discussion" section (e.g. strengths / weaknesses of the study).

  • Order procedures chronologically or by type of procedure (subheaded) and chronologically within type.

  • Take inspiration from how others have written their methodology.

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
The methodology ...

  • covers a description of material (e.g. input data and its characteristics), description of methods, and analytical procedures (e.g. statistical tests), and is organized chronologically.

  • is written in past tense (it describes what was done).

  • is written on a suitable technical level.

  • describes and specifies the appropriate controls or comparators.

  • clearly explains how all of the data in the Results section were obtained.

  • does not show any results (only procedures) or include information that belong in other sections.

  • cites original research if the study uses methodologies described by others,

  • clears any ethical concerns if applicable (e.g. that the study obtained appropriate ‘informed consent’ documents)

  • allows other to repeat the same experiment given the same data.

docs.title: Process
docs.text: Below is a suggested process presented which aims to make the report writing efficient.

docs.title: Define the idea and message
docs.text:
Initially define the idea and message that should be transmitted. The message should obviously be based on the performed original research and the results obtained (i.e. the unique contribution of the work).

There are several ways to reinforce the report's message:

  • logical order
  • repetition
  • Organization

docs.title: Organization (high-level)
docs.text: Identify the core sections of the report.

docs.title: Organization (low-level)
docs.text:
This is one of the most important steps. Identify the low-level structure in each core section. The process of dividing content into a skeleton is often very helpful for the writing process, as the set structure serves as a guiding framework for writing.

This is done by dividing and ordering the content into informative sections in order to support the contribution (i.e. the original research) of the report.

docs.title: Recycle
docs.text: Identify which parts of the project specification and the pre-study that can be recycled for the report

docs.title: Bullet points and placeholders
docs.text: Setting the structure helps to realize if the report tends to become too complex/detailed/naive/premature/shallow.

docs.title: Iterate
docs.text: Writing is dynamic process

docs.title: Report components
docs.text: Below are explained the fundamental components that are common to every report.

docs.title: Cover and title page
docs.text:
Before submitting the final report it should be wrapped by the official KTH thesis cover to give it a uniform cover (back and front). The cover is generated using this online form.

It is recommended to maintain the title page of the report template in order to indicate the examiner and the supervisor(s) which do not show up on the KTH cover page.

Read more

docs.title: Abstract
docs.text: The abstract summarizes the report. It does so by being a condensed version of the report's separate sections: Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion.

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
• Provide the reader with a background to the study in a couple of sentences.
  • Explain what is already known and what is not known about the subject.

docs.title: Methods
docs.text:
• Provide enough information to enable the reader to understand what was done and how.

  • Which method and evaluation measures were used?

docs.title: Results
docs.text: This is the most important part of the abstract since it contains the findings of the study. It should therefore be the longest part of the abstract.

docs.title: Conclusions
docs.text:
Finally, write down the most important take-home message of the study. It can also include a short mentioning of the implications of the study.

Reference: Indian journal of psychiatry

Remember: The abstract should be written in both English and Swedish. Avoid to make the Swedish version a literal translation of the English one, but try to write it in a natural language.

Tip

Write the abstracts as the last component of the report. It has dependencies on all other core sections.

docs.title: Table of contents
docs.text:
The skeleton of a scientific report is its structure which is composed of main sections and subsections. They should be organized in a logical order to help reinforce the report's scientific contribution and story line.

It is important to have a balanced section structure. Only introduce subsections if the main section (X) will contain at least two of subsections (e.g. X.1 and X.2).


1 Introduction
  1.1 Topic 1 (remove!)
2 Background
  2.1 Topic 1
  2.2 Topic 2
  2.3 Topic 3

For the table of contents, it is highly recommended to

  • auto-generate the table of contents in the text editor (don't write it manually),

  • use the section titles to reinforce the report's message and reveal the story line. For example, repeat key points (typically from the title and abstract) in the section titles,

  • make it easy to navigate between different parts of the report (add hyperlinks),

  • assure that the structure is informative and concise (avoid being too detailed or too condensed)

docs.title: Bibliography
docs.text:
The bibliography is the final section of the report and includes a complete list of sources that were used to develop the research project. Complete citations (including the author's name, the title, publisher, year pubilshed, page numbers, URLs) should be listed for any in-text citation in the report. The latter should provide a brief idea where the information to support a specific statement in the report can be found.

There exist many different bibliographic styles for referencing and citing literature. Popular styles for scientific reports include IEEE, ACM, Harvard, Chicago, APA, etc. The most important is not which style to use, but to be consequent and stick to only one throughout the report. This is easily achieved by letting the reference manager and/or text editor (e.g. BibTeX) handle the generation of cited sources according to the selected style.

  • ACM, APA: Lists references alphabetically, using the author's last name.
  • IEEE: Lists references numerically, in the order they have been cited.

Notice the difference in citing a journal article, internet resource, and book.

docs.title: Report: Results
docs.text:
The Results section is often the shortest section of the report. Nevertheless, it is the undisputed core and most important part of the report as it presents the data, which from here on is the new truth. It is on these results that the reader can form opinions and plan future research.

For that purpose, the results must be presented in a purely objective manner. Subjective interpretation and discussion around the results are deferred until the next section of the report (i.e. Discussion section).

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
Before starting to write this section, think about

  • what "story" does your data tell?
  • which graphs, tables, and data are absolutely necessary for telling the story?
  • which is the key graph/table for your work?

Make a deliberate choice early in the writing process on which key findings to present in visuals (tables/figures).

Often the results section is a mirror of the methods section. For every method (what you did), there should be a corresponding result (what you found) and vice versa.

Finally, findings in the results section should match and answer the research questions from the introduction

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
The result section

  • contains both numerical data (figures/tables) AND narrative text that guide the reader to the important results and connects results to each other,
  • has a logical structure (i.e. starts with the simple results and builds up to the more complex results),
  • is clearly written (in past tense),
  • contains only data has been properly obtained and processed,
  • contains all necessary result elements,
  • does not include description of experimental methods,
  • explains the findings objectively (i.e. does not include any interpretation or discussion of the data),

docs.title: Figures and tables
docs.text:
The key findings should be presented in tables and figures. There is usually no need to do both for the same data. Only if the data is very complex it is justified to present the same results in both figures and table format,

In general, each visual (figure/table) should

  • be critical to the report,
  • has a caption that explains it,
  • be chronologically indexed and referenced in the narrative text,
  • be carefully designed and prepared,
  • be as self-explanatory as possible.

Formatting:

  • All elements of the figure are viewable without zooming.
  • The table/figure caption contains a label (e.g. Fig. 1), the title (e.g. "Principal component analysis of test data") and a narrative legend that describes the key features of the figure.
  • Avoid titles in the figure itself, keep them in the caption.
  • Axes have labels (physical quantity AND unit).
  • Complex figures can be divided into panels (a,b,c, etc).
  • Try to position the image AFTER where it was introduced in the text.
  • Avoid screenshots. Export the graph in a proper format.

docs.title: Scientific writing
docs.text:
A scientific report is aimed at exposing an idea and to present evidences in favor of that idea. A good scientific report should therefore be clear and concise, nuanced and well-argued, and to the point. It arrives at an answer to a specific question, but also opens up for new questions.

To be able to write any text, including a scientific report, it is always helpful to understand the readership. In contrast to most other literature, scientific texts are rarely read linearly (page to page), but the experienced scientific reader is usually very selective while reading and searches for the parts that can be of most interest in order to quickly judge the relevance of the work.

docs.title: Report structure
docs.text:
In order to facilitate selective reading, scientific reports are usually built up from a common high-level structure (core structure). Although each report is different, all of them follows a standard format and naturally share many components and sections.

The core structure (high level structure) is made up by the fundamental chapters/sections of the scientific report which are expected to be easily found by the reader. Therefore they generally repeat from one report to another:

  • Introduction
  • Background
  • Methodology
  • Results
  • Discussion
  • Conclusions

The core structure is rigid and disconnected from the topic of the report. Although it may not represent the way/order in which science always happens, it provides a standardized scope for original research and allows for non-linear reading.

Given this structure, the report should start by providing the broad picture (Introduction) and the more detailed background (theory and related work) that justifies the methodology that has been chosen to answer the research question. The report's unique contribution is then described (Methodology and Results), which is finally discussed and contrasted to what was already known (Discussion and conclusion).

One often depicts the structure of a scientific report as an "hourglass" (Mišak et al., 2005).

       Go from the general, broad context of your work,
           to tell the reader what is already known,
                to what is not yet known or,
                   what the problems are,
                     to what you have
                         decided
                          to do

                    Methods and results
    (i.e. the original part of the study = contribution)

                           After
                        summarizing
                    the results, identify
                   limitations and biases,
                 compare and contrast them
              with previous findings and discuss
          theoretical and practical implications of your
         own, make cautious speculations and suggest future
      research, show what is new and how your results fit into
  the broad field you described at the  beginning of the introduction

docs.title: Standard report components
docs.text:
Besides the common core sections (see above), all reports should also contain the following components:

  • Title page
  • Abstract
  • Table of contents
  • Bibliography
  • Appendix [optional]

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
Read, read, read

Spend significant time to find and read high-quality literature relevant for your research topic. It will help you to choose your methods and to narrow down your research question.

Learn from previous thesis works

Use the library to find published engineering master's theses. Explore many theses, both in your own and in other fields.

  • What common structure do they all share?
  • Are the research questions stated implicitly or explicitly?
  • How have the students narrowed down their research question?
  • Focus on the introductory chapters. How do they relate to Assignment 1?

docs.title: Build structure
docs.text:
Figure out the different sections of the text.

Use the section titles to tell the story: It should be possible to read out the idea of the thesis only from the table of contents

Writing is a continuous process

A good project description is not written in one day. It has to mature. Therefore, create a draft on the very first day, and then continuously edit it (add/remove/change/reconsider) until you hand it in.

Note

"Finns det en underrubrik på en viss nivå i ett avsnitt, så bör det normalt finnas minst två (annars haltar trädstrukturen i dokumentet)."

docs.title: Final formatting
docs.text:
References

There are many ways to cite an article. Show different examples. In all cases, the citation should be included next to the text. Do "... blah blah [REF]", and not "... blah blah. [REF]"

Abbreviations

Introduce abbreviations in the text when they first appear. Thereafter, use only the abbreviation.

Numbers

Numbers from zero to ten are written with letters (i.e. one, two, three, etc). Numbers above ten (i.e. 11, 12, etc) are written with figures.

Avoid contractions

Replace "don't" with "do not", and so on.

Get some distance to your text

Before you hand in your text, give yourself some distance to it. Let it rest for a day, before you return to read it with fresh and critical eyes.

Grammar and spelling

Kör (stavnings- och) grammatik-kontroll på texterna som lämnas in.
